content: After I was cut by the Detroit Lions, I got picked up by the Dallas Cowboys.
On top of all the physical training, I had to learn all of the plays. AND I had just started a graduate program in
Materials Science & Engineering at the University of Virginia shortly before training camp started.
Keeping up with classes on top of NFL training was exhausting. I had never worked so hard. But after my hamstring injury
I knew I needed a safety net.
I was playing well but I had learned my lesson. Science had been my passion since my first chemistry set explosion and if
anything happened I knew I could be just as happy becoming a scientist.
The Cowboy's playbook was huge! There weren't enough hours in the day to read everything. I needed a system to help me memorize
my routes, something visual and quick.
and luckily it wasn't a football at practice!
It was an idea. I had learned basic computer programming in high school.
And I had a laptop. I programmed flashcards onto my computer so my plays would always be in front of me as I worked or studied.
They weren't the most amazing things in the world, but they got the job done. Every time the quarterback called a play I
could see the card in my head.
You never know when something you learn will help you through a new challenge.
Science and technology helped me juggle a heavy schedule and be a better wide receiver.
A little know-how can go a long way!
